info.title: Building Energy Modeling API description
info.description:
# Overview ## API overview and usage This document explains the usage of the `Building Energy Modeling` API. This API has three main purposes: 1. Build a baseline model of a building using the “thermal signature” models recommended by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air‑Conditioning (ASHRAE) and the International Performance Measurement and Verification Protocol (IPMVP), typically from one year of historical data. Optionally assess its statistical quality to compute savings. 2. Optionally build a target model using the same mechanism, typically from one year of simulated target data (assuming the user has created simulated target data). 3. Follow-up the baseline and target models of a building in particular to detect faults and to compute savings. This document provides a general tutorial for users who want to consume the Building Energy Modeling API. ## How it works The Building Energy Modeling API usage flow is described below. First you need to create a model through the create service. This service will return a modelId and other model information. Once the model is created it is possible to either make a consumption prediction using the apply service or determine if your model is good enough for savings computation through the assess quality for savings service. __Create__ This service receives as input a multivariate time-series. Each column of this table represents a variable (feature or the target) and each row represents an observation. At least one of these columns must describe the target you want to model. Create service also receives only one configuration object composed of one or several section(s) depending on request customization. __Columns configuration__ This configuration object is the only mandatory one. It marks which columns to use in the input table: * target (Mandatory): What you want to model (most of the time, it is energy consumption related). * meanTemperature, minTemperature, maxTemperature (Mandatory): outside air temperature needed to model building signature. __Note__ You need either meanTemperature or (minTemperature + maxTemperature) or both. With all temperature data, BEM will automatically choose the best degree days formula available. * otherFeatures (Optional): Input table features that have an influence on your target. For example : production counts, occupancy, exterior heating input to the building. * positiveFeatures (Optional): Features among otherFeatures that are known as positive influence on your target, meaning its increase is correlated to target increase. For example : production numbers, occupancy. __Note__ To sum up, for a daily energy model you will typically need: * An “energy consumption” column (the target) * An outside air temperature columns(mean and / or minmax) * Maybe an optional other columns that are known to influence energy consumption. __dayGroups__ configuration An optional configuration object dedicated to your building working calendar: * __dayGroupCol__ : may be present to activate explicit time binning. Indeed it is very frequent that a building has several models, one for each working mode, the most common one being : opened and closed days. This column is the only one not requiring numerical data. If this column is provided, a sub-model will be created for each unique element. * __improveCalendar__ : chooses whether you want BEM to find a better calendar repartition of the week. This extends computation time. __Note__ __improveCalendar__ is usable with or without a dayGroupCol parameter : If __dayGroupCol__ is provided, improveCalendar will run on combination of already existing groups. If no __dayGroupCol__ is provided, improveCalendar will run on all possible day of week combinations. * __maxMergedDayGroups__ : linked to __improveCalendar__ parameter, BEM will explore days of week configurations up to a maximum number of groups. For example: 3 means every slicing of 3 groups or lower. It is not recommended to go higher than 3 since the building rarely has more than 3 different working modes per week. __temporal__ configuration An optional configuration object dedicated to customize the temporal resolution of your train data: * __resolution__ : selects whether you want your building signatures and results to be in daily or monthly resolution. It also indicates to BEM your target format. * daily means that your input table contains data on a daily basis (target and others columns). * monthly means that your input table contains target data once a month, on each first day, representing the monthly consumption. __Note__ * On Monthly mode : Any other column (Temperature, Feature) still have to be daily input. * There are some parameters incompatable with the Monthly mode, do not use them: improveCalendar, robustRegression, degreeDaysMode. * Default mode is daily. __Warning__ * For daily mode, the train table has to contain at least 80 exploitable days of observations (80 non-NaN rows) * For monthly mode, the train table has to contain at least 8 monthly target observations (8 x ~30 rows for other columns) __computation__ configuration An optional configuration object dedicated to customize computation options. This is an advanced user configuration object: * __degreeDaysMode__ : Select the degree days computing methods that will be parsed by BEM : Basic or Advanced. See degree days formulas __Warning__ only use on TemporalConfig['resolution'] == “daily” * __buildingSignatures__ : Select the types of building signature that will be parsed by BEM. See thermal signatures __Note__ Reducing the scope of building signature to explore is recommended when you have information on your building heatingcooling technologies : + No cooling devices -> use [twoParameters”,”threeParametersHeating”] + No heating devices -> use [twoParameters”,”threeParametersCooling”] * __robustRegression__ : Select whether the regression is sensible to outliers or not. This is useful if you have already cleaned your data from outliers : * False value will use a LinearRegression. * True value will use a RANSACRegressor. __Note__ robustRegression means a model robust to outliers but at the price of longer computation time. No robustRegression means faster response time, but user has to be sure to input representative data. __Warning__ only use on TemporalConfig['resolution'] == “daily” * autoApply : Selects whether BEM executes an apply of the computed model directly on its training table. This is useful when you just want a full ID card of this year : * Model, Model information and metrics : * BEMModel * RegressionMetrics * Prediction table on training set. See apply output table for details. __Apply__ The test table provided to the apply service has to fit the exact same criteria as those required for the create service input table __Note__ This table can be the exact same table than the one provided in the create service. Apply parameters faultDetection, decide which type of fault detection you want BEM to apply to your test dataset : “both” or True (default): Considered both over and under consumptions as fault. “overconsumption” : Considered only over consumption as fault. “underconsumption” : Considered only under consumption as fault. False : Do not consider any fault detection. __Note__ In the No fault detection case: * The target becomes optional in the test dataset. * faultDetectionThresholdNbStd and removeFaultsFromSavings parameter becomes useless faultDetectionThresholdNbStd determines the standard deviation coefficient up to which a TARGET value is considered normal. The default values is 2 sigma. see fault_detection_limits removeFaultsFromSavings determines whether savings are kept in accumulation computation or not for anomaly points in test dataset. The output of the apply service is a prediction table which is basically the same as the one provided as input with some added columns and exact same rows. Here a list of added columns: * discarded_for_model_creation * prediction * prediction_residual * cumulative_prediction_residual, cumulative_savings and cumulative_savings_ * fault_detection_upper_limit and fault_detection_lower_limit * consumption_anomaly * midrange_temperature * reference_temperature * heating_degree_days and cooling_degree_days * predicted_DRIVER_contribution * estimated_actual_DRIVER_contribution * NTS_DRIVER_predicted_energy and NTS_DRIVER_actual_energy __Note__ For following descriptions other columns than those added are referred: * TARGET: Target provided by the user * DRIVER: Driver provided by the user * DAYGROUP: Day group either provided by the user or computed by the component __discarded_for_model_creation__ This column is an autoApply context only. It represents which points were ultimately used for thermal signatures models creation. __Warning__ * Points marked True in this columns are not outliers, in the “aberrant value” sense, See consumption_anomaly columns. * Results in this column will vary a lot depending of the robustRegression parameter value. __prediction__ Prediction of the provided TARGET made by the BuildingEnergyModeling component. For each day group we have: where __prediction_residual__ The prediction residual is the prediction error. __cumulative_prediction_residual, cumulative_savings and cumulative_savings___ This represents the sum of differences between ground truth and prediction on the TARGET, expressed in the same physical unit. It is called cumulative_savings in an apply context, cumulative_savings_DAYGROUP represent the cumulative savings made for a specific day group. The cumulative_prediction_residual is used in an autoApply context, as the word “savings” does not make much sense here. The computation formula stays the same in either case: where: __k__ is the number of rows in the provided table. __Note__ cumulative_prediction_residual can be useful if it displays a cyclic pattern in values, this most probably means that there is at least another hidden feature influencing the target value ! __fault_detection_upper_limit and fault_detection_lower_limit__ Respectively values upper and bellow which a TARGET observation is considered as an anomaly. These values directly depends on the faultDetectionThresholdNbStd value on apply context, and is fixed at default value 2.0 in an autoApply context. __consumption_anomaly__ Boolean flag informing if a TARGET observation is or not considered as an anomaly. Warning * This column is present in autoApply model creation context. * In apply context, this column is piloted by the faultDetection parameter. __midrange_temperature__ The day midrange temperature represent an approximation of the day average temperature with following formula: __Warning__ This metric is only computed when both minTemperature and maxTemperature are provided. __reference_temperature__ Since every day group model may use a different temperature value (average or midrange temperature), this column gathered in a single one the reference temperature value used by each day groups. __heating_degree_days__ and __cooling_degree_days__ Respectively values of computed heating and cooling degree days. For more information see Degree days. __predicted_DRIVER_contribution__ The special predicted_other_uses_of_energy_contribution is equal to the intercept. If the model is 2-parameters, predicted_heating_degree_days_contribution or predicted_cooling_degree_days_contribution will be filled depending on the slope. Note that we choose to NOT provide a predicted_reference_temperature_contrib because the result would be harder to understand. __Note__ On every row, the sum of all such predicted contributions should be equal to the prediction column __estimated_actual_DRIVER_contribution__ That is, we prorate the actual energy with the proportions of contribution of this driver in the model. __Note__ On every row, the sum of all such estimated actual contributions should be equal to the provided TARGET column __NTS_DRIVER_predicted_energy__ and __NTS_DRIVER_actual_energy__ Normalized Thermal Signature (NTS) columns. By default the building thermal signature is just obtained by plotting the scatter plot of prediction (line) and TARGET (dots) (y axis) against the reference_temperature (x axis). However in case of additional drivers the resulting scatter plot is flawed by the influence of these extra drivers. To circumvent this one can plot a so-called “normalized” version of the thermal signature, obtained for each driver by plotting NTS_DRIVER_predicted_energy (line) and NTS_DRIVER_actual_energy (dots) (y axis) against the DRIVER (x axis). Equations are: Last but not the least (as they will be the most used), a special NTS_reference_temperature_predicted_energy is computed by merging the predicted energies of cdd and hdd drivers: __assess_quality_for_savings__ This service answers the question “is my model good enough to compute statistically significant savings?”. Its main parameters are the target savings ratio (20%, 30%), and the assessment period (30 days, 60 days, 365 days). The larger the target savings, and the longer the assessment period, the less precise a model needs to be. On the other hand if the savings ratio to achieve is small (e.g. 1%, 5%) and/or if the assessment period is short (e.g. 10 days, 30 days) the uncertainty will be bigger and certifying the savings will require a much more precise model. # Documentation ## Getting started These are the minimal steps to use this component through its APIs. __Authentication__ Authentication is mandatory to use this API product. API_KEY must be included in the Authorization header of each request. To see how you can obtain your API KEY please refer How to signup section. Sample requests included as examples below. __Create model__ First step is to create a trained model with: * configuration parameters, e.g.: ```json { "configuration": { "columns":{ "target": "energy_consumption", "meanTemperature": ["mean_temperature"] } } } ``` __Note__ * These are the minimal configuration parameters that can be used to train a model. * For advanced usage, see the complete /create API description. * training data, e.g.: ```json { "trainTbl": { "format": "row_objects_indexed", "indexName": "timestamp", "rows": { "2016-05-20": { "energy_consumption": 479.157, "mean_temperature": 19.1 }, "2016-05-21": { "energy_consumption": 478.475, "mean_temperature": 16.8 } } } } ``` __Apply model__ Second step is to apply the created model to other data to make a prediction, with: * the previously returned modelId * some data to apply the model on, e.g.: ```json { "testTbl": { "format": "row_objects_indexed", "indexName": "timestamp", "rows": { "2016-05-20": { "energy_consumption": 400.0, "mean_temperature": 42.0 }, "2016-05-21": { "energy_consumption": 500.0, "mean_temperature": 69.0 } } } } ``` For advanced usage, see the complete /apply API description. ## How to sign up Before you can sign up for the `Building Energy Modeling` API, you must register or login with an Exchange account. Then you can subscribe to the API product in our Shop and where you can read about terms & conditions. After subscription, you will find your API key prepopulated in the Try Out console. Note: If you're an existing V1 consumer then you do not need to subscribe again. Your existing API key will work for calling both V1 and V2 APIs. Select one of the endpoints and click on . Select Production as the target environment . Your API key is shown in the Try Out console Status of your API consumption will soon be available from the Exchange cockpit ## Table formats * Below described are all possible input table formats. * By default table returned after an apply will have the same format as the one provided in the input. __TableRowFormat__ ```json { "format": "rows", "indexName": "Date", "columnNames": ["Date", 3728.927799999993, "T_mean": 0.2, "T_min": -2.0, "T_max": 3.0, "Shipment_RMB": 2506211.045, "daytype_basic": "SaturdaysMondays"} ] } ``` ## Thermal signature __What is a Thermal signature?__ The thermal signature of a building describes the energy consumption of a building considering external temperature. Basically it models how much energy a building will require for heating when external temperature is cold (heating degree days, HDD) and how much energy it will require for cooling when external temperature is hot (cooling degree days, CDD). The heating change-point is the outside air temperature below which the heating system is on. The cooling change-point is the outside air temperature above which cooling system is on. See Degree days section for more information. There are 5 types of change-point models according to ASHRAE guideline 14, appendix D4: * 2-parameters * 3-parameters-heating * 3-parameters-cooling * 4-parameters * 5-parameters __Note__ All these model types are able to take into account additional drivers (production, occupancy…). These drivers will be considered to have a linear impact on energy, independently on the weather’s impact. __2-parameters__ The 2-parameters model is a straight line with no change-points. It can model either a heating season only, a cooling season only or a building without heating or cooling. __3-parameters-heating__ The slope heating 3-parameters model includes a linear dependency with HDD: when outside air temperature is below a change-point value, energy linearly depends on it ; above it is a constant. See the example below. 3-parameters heating models are used to model energy consumption in buildings without cooling system, or to model the energy consumption of heating equipments alone (using a sub-meter). __3-parameters-cooling__ The slope cooling 3-parameters model includes a linear dependency with CDD: when outside air temperature is above a change-point value, energy linearly depends on it ; below it is a constant. See the example below. 3-parameters cooling models are used to model energy consumption in buildings without heating system, or to model the energy consumption of cooling equipments alone (using a sub-meter). __4-parameters__ The 4-parameters model includes one linear dependency for heating (HDD) and another for cooling (CDD), with a single shared change-point between the two. 4-parameter models are appropriate to model heating and cooling energy consumption in buildings where there is no inter-seasonal behavior: there are almost no days in the year where the heating and cooling systems are both off. Note that these models can correctly take into account days where both heating and cooling are on, if an appropriate degree days calculation methods is used (by default this component searches for the best method). __5-parameters__ The 5-parameters model includes one linear dependency for heating (HDD) and another for cooling (CDD), with one dedicated change-point for each mode. Unlike the 4-parameter model, the 5-parameter model is able to model heating and cooling energy consumption in buildings where there is an inter-seasonal behavior with both systems turned off. Note that these models can correctly take into account days where both heating and cooling are on, if an appropriate degree days calculation methods is used (by default this component searches for the best method). ## Degree days __What are degree days?__ Degree days are a specialist kind of weather data providing a simplified representation of outside-air-temperature data. They are calculated from readings of outside air temperature and mainly used in calculations relating to building energy consumption. It is possible to distinguish two kinds of degree days: * “Heating degree days”, or “HDD”, are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was lower than a specific “base temperature” (or “heating change-point”). They are used for calculations relating to the energy consumption required to heat buildings. * “Cooling degree days”, or “CDD”, are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was higher than a specific “base temperature” (or “cooling change-point”). They are used for calculations relating to the energy consumption required to cool buildings. __Note__ * It is possible for a building to only have HDD or CDD * It is possible for heating change-points and cooling change-points to be equal * The thermal signature of a building will depend on the presence/absence of HDD and CDD as well as the number of different change-points __Example__ Considering a building with a base temperature of 17°C and a single day, let’s say July 1st, with an average outside air temperature at 16°C. So, on July 1st, the mean outside air temperature (16°C) was 1 degree below the base temperature of the building (17°C), and we can work out the heating degree days on that day like so: __degree_days = ( 17 - 16 ) * 1 = 1 degree days__ Base temperature As seen above, the calculation of degree days requires to define a base temperature for both HDD and CDD. If you are not sure which temperatures to use for your building, keep reading. Base temperature (Tbase) can be physically interpreted as the outdoor temperature at which solar and internal gains offset heat losses (Eto, 1988 [5]). As can be seen, the base temperature is not easy to calculate. It is different for each building and climatic zone. Anyway, the following table gives different standard values for different countries (Spinoni, Vogt, & Barbosa, 2015) | Country | Base Heating Degree Days|Base Cooling Degree Days| Source | ---------------- | ------------| ------------| ------------| | Turkey | 14-22°C | 28°C | Buyukalaca et al. (2001) [1] | Spain | 15°C | 21°C | Valor et al. (2001) [13] | Greece | 10-20°C | 27.5°C | Papakostas et al. (2010) [9] | Canada | 18°C | 18°C | Wibig (2003) [14] | United States | 18.3°C | 18.3°C | Wibig (2003) [14] | United Kingdom | 15.5°C | 22°C | UK Met-Office [12] | France | 18°C | 18°C | COSTIC [3] Despite these general references, every Energy Manager can use their own base temperatures (per building, per project, etc) according to specific project needs or previous experience. __Implemented degree days formulas__ Depending on provided information, the BuildingEnergyModeling component will calculate degree days using different methods: * Basic * UK Met-Office * COSTIC __Note__ For all the following degree days formulas we have:

Basic

__For Heating Degree Days (HDD)__ __For Cooling Degree Days (CDD)__

UK Met-Office

This method was developed by the UK Met-Office in 1928 (CIBSE, 2006)[2], daily Heating Degree Days (HDD) and Cooling Degree Days (CDD) are calculated based on a comparison of daily minimum and maximum air temperatures with the selected base temperature, taking account of fluctuations of daily air temperature around the base temperature, as well as the asymmetry between daily average temperature and diurnal temperature variations. The UK Met-Office equations for computing daily HDD and CDD are shown below (Matzarakis & Balafoutis, 2004)[7] (Spinoni et al., 2018)[11]: For Heating Degree Days (HDD) For Cooling Degree Days (CDD)

COSTIC

This method is the standard of the Scientific and Technical Committee of the Climatic Industries of France, also called the Method of Energy Professionals. The Unified Day Degree (Degré jour unifié - DJU) is the difference between the outside temperature and a reference temperature which allows estimates of thermal energy consumption to keep a building comfortable in proportion to the harshness of winter or the heat of the summer. The usual reference of 18°C was defined by considering that the interior temperature of the premises is 19°C and that the free internal (occupants, lighting, equipment, etc.) and external (solar radiation, etc.) supplies cover the equivalent of 1°C of heat loss. They are therefore divided into heating degree-days (DJC) and cooling degree-days (DJF). There are two methods of calculating DJU giving different results: a method called “météo” (Météo-France, 2017) 8 with simple calculation and a method called “Professionnels de l’énergie” or “COSTIC method” with more elaborate calculation (COSTIC, 2020)[#f3]_. The COSTIC calculation method is the recommended one by the French government (GEM/CC), 2007 6 and it’s the following: For Heating Degree Days (HDD) For Cooling Degree Days (CDD)

References

[1] Buyukalaca O, Bulut H, Yilmaz T. 2001. Analysis of variable-baseheating and cooling degree-days for Turkey. Appl. Energy 69 (4): 269–283

[2] CIBSE. 2006. Degree-days: theory and application. Technical Manual41. Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers: London,UK. ISBN-10: 1-903287-76-6. https://www.cibse.org/knowledge/knowledge-items/detail?id=a0q20000008I73TAAS

[3] COSTIC, « https://www.costic.com/ressources-techniques-et-reglementaires/service-degres-jours-unifies », consulted on (19/02/2020).

[4] Degree Days, 2020. https://www.degreedays.net/calculation, consulted on (20/02/2020)

[5] Eto, J. H. (1988). On using degree-days to account for the effects of weather on annual energy use in office buildings. Energy and Buildings, 113-127. Obtained from https://doi.org/10.1016/0378-7788(88)90073-4

[6] Groupe d’étude des marchés de chauffage et de climatisation (GEM/CC), 2007. Guide de rédaction des clauses techniques des marchés publics d’exploitation de chauffage avec ou sans gros entretien des matériels et avec obligation de résultat: Paris, France, Ministère de l’Économie des Finances et de l’Industrie. Obtained from: https://www.economie.gouv.fr/daj/guide-redaction-des-clauses-techniques-des-marches-publics-dexploitation-chauffage-avec-ou-sans

[7] Matzarakis, A., & Balafoutis, C. (2004). Heating degree-days over Greece as an index of energy consumption. International Journal of Climatology, 1817 - 1828. doi:10.1002/joc.1107

[8] Météo-France, « Degres jours unifies - DJU », Relevés et statistiques, 2017 (consulted on 19/02/2020).

[9] Papakostas, K., Mavromatis, T., & Kyriakis, N. (2010). Impact of the ambient temperature rise on the energy consumption for heating and cooling in residential buildings of Greece. Renewable Energy, 35(7), 1376-1379.

[10] Spinoni, J., Vogt, J., & Barbosa, P. (2015). European degree-day climatologies and trends for the period 1951-2011. International Journal of Climatology, 25-36. doi:10.1002/joc.3959. Obtained from https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/joc.3959

[11] Spinoni, J., Vogt, J. V., Barbosa, P., Dosio, A., McCormick, N., Bigano, A., & Füssel, H. (2018). Changes of heating and cooling degree‐days in Europe from 1981 to 2100, 38, e191–e208. doi:10.1002/joc.5362

[12] UK Met-Office, 2020. http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/

[13] Valor, E., Meneu, V., & Caselles, V. (2001). Daily Air Temperature and Electricity Load in Spain. Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology, 1413-1421. Obtained from https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0450(2001)040%3C1413:DATAEL%3E2.0.CO;2

[14](1,2) Wibig J. 2003. Heating degree days and cooling degree days variabilityin Lodz in the period 1931–2000. In Fifth International Conferenceon Urban Climate. Lodz, Poland
## Building calendar __What is a “building calendar”?__ A building calendar is the representation of the working process of a building. It means that it gathers days with similar energy consumption profiles e.g.: week days / week-end days. __Example__ Following picture represents a building with a calendar constitute by 3 day-groups: * NormalDays: Nominal mode of the building with a 5-parameters. * SaturdaysMondays: Slowed down activity with a 4-parameters. * Sundays: No activity (only basal consumption) with a 2-parameters. How are building calendar computed? __Warning__ Following informations are true only for the “daily” mode. “Monthly” mode only tolerates one single day group. Following are described methods used by the BuildingEnergyComponent to compute the building calendar: * Don’t try to improve the building calendar * Try to improve the building calendar __Don’t try to improve the building calendar__ If the `BuildingEnergyComponent` is called with the instruction of not trying to improve the building calendar two scenarios are possible: * __The user didn’t provide its own building calendar__: In this case all observations are gathered within the same single day group. Only one model is computed. * __The user provided its own building calendar__: In this case a sub-model (also named day group model) is computed for each day groups. In addition to global model performance metrics, all of these sub-models will all have their own performance metrics computed. Computed sub-models may have different thermal signatures. __Try to improve the building calendar__ If the `BuildingEnergyComponent` is called with the instruction of trying to improve the building calendar two scenarios are possible (same as previously): * __The user didn’t provide its own building calendar__: In this case the component will try to gather observations according to the day of the week (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday…). Once week days are gathered within day groups, a sub-model (also named day group model) is computed for each day groups. In addition to global model performance metrics, all of these sub-models will all have their own performance metrics computed. Computed sub-models may have different thermal signatures. * __The user provided its own building calendar__: In this case the component will try to gather observations according to their associated day group. After that a sub-model (also named day group model) is computed for each day groups. In addition to global model performance metrics, all of these sub-models will all have their own performance metrics computed. Computed sub-models may have different thermal signatures. ## Response Codes We follow the error response format proposed in RFC 7807 also known as Problem Details for HTTP APIs. As with our normal API responses, your client must be prepared to gracefully handle additional members of the response. **The below table defines the HTTP Status codes that this API may return** | HTTP Status Code | Error Reason| | ---------------- | ------------| | 400
UnknownIdError | The model stored cannot be found with the current model ID.| | 401
APIKeyMissing | Your request did not include an API key.This error suggests that your API key was missing from your request, or that something was formatted or named improperly in your header. Other reason could be: APIKeyInvalid: Your API key may be invalid, or you've attempted to access the wrong data center. Check that your API key was input correctly, and verify which data center to access. | | 403
Forbidden | You are not permitted to access this resource. This is a generic error. Other reasons could be: UserDisabled: This account has been disabled. WrongDatacenter: The API key provided is linked to a different data center. This error suggests that you tried to contact the wrong data center. It's often associated with misconfigured libraries. | | 404
ResourceNotFound | The requested resource could not be found. This error tells you a specific resource doesn't exist. It's possible that the resource has been moved or deleted, or that there's a typo in your request.| | 422
RequestValidationError | An input is invalid| | 422
OutdatedModelError | The stored model is outdated.| | 422
TableConversionError | Provided table cannot be processed. It is probably due to a bad datetime column format.| | 422
InvalidDatetimeError | Unexpected datetime.| | 422
SamplingDeclarationError | Datetime column doesn’t fit the expected sampling (1-day).| | 422
MissingMandatoryColumnError | One or several expected columns of the input table are missing.| | 422
MandatoryColumnWrongExpectedTypeError | One or several columns have an unexpected type.| | 422
NotEnoughObservationsErrorModel | Provided input table is empty.| | 422
DuplicatedTimestampsErrorModel | Datetime column contain one or several duplicated items.| | 422
NotMonotonicIncreasingTimestampsError | Datetime column is not monotonic increasing.| | 422
NonUniformSamplingError | Datetime column of the input dataset is not uniform: all time steps encountered are not multiple of the minimal one.| | 422
InvalidTimedeltaError | Unexpected timesteps in the datetime column. Expected timesteps: modulo 1-day.| | 422
WrongExpectedTimeDeltaCoverageError | The datetime column contains too many gaps between consecutive records. The expected timesteps (1 day) is observed between less than 75% of rows.| | 422
WrongNbOfMonthlyObservationsError | Found several energy values for the same month. When temporal resolution is monthly, a single energy value per month is allowed.| | 422
WrongMonthlyInformationErrorModel | Found an energy value at a date that is not a month start. When temporal resolution is monthly, the mean monthly energy value should be provided in the first day of the month.| | 422
WrongDayGroupNbError | Found several day group values. When temporal resolution is monthly, day groups do not make sense and should not be used.| | 422
ModelMigrationError | The model stored cannot be used with the current application version, please re-create a new model.| | 422
TemporalResolutionRestrictionError | Found configuration incompatibility with Temporal_resolution and other parametersWhen temporal resolution is monthly, improve_calendar and robust_regression cannot be true, and degree_days_mode cannot be in advanced mode| | 429
TooManyRequests | You have exceeded the limit of 10 simultaneous connections. When you reach the connection limit, we'll throttle the server response. If any of your requests time out after you've reached the limit, those requests could still be considered open and continue to slow your connection.| ## Deprecation of V1 With effect from Dec 2023, the `Building Energy Modeling` V1 APIs are deprecated. They are replaced by V2 APIs which run with the latest code and on a new platform. They have more structured request-response format and provide better precision in terms of generating energy consumption preditions. They have the same auth mechanism as V1 so the existing API Key used when calling the V1 APIs will also work for calling the V2 APIs. If you are currently using V1 APIs then we strongly recommend that you to migrate to V2 APIs. Please refer "Migrating to V2" section for more details. ## Migrating to V2 The `Building Energy Modeling` V2 APIs are built on top of the new backend platform and run with the latest code when compared to V1. They provide better precision in terms of predicting the energy model and offer a better way to structure the request and response payloads, yet provide similar functionality as V1 thereby keeping the migration impact minimal. The BEM V2 has the following operations: 1. Create 2. Apply 3. Assess quality for savings Note: The "Get model information" operation(available in V1) has been removed in V2, as essentially it returns the same model information as the Create service. In order to facilitate easy migration from V1 to V2, a mapping recipe has been prepared that provides a detailed view of request-response paramater mappings. If you need any further help in terms of migration then please do not hesitate to contact us (see Support). Migrating to BEM API V2.pdf ## Support Contact the SE Exchange support team at exchange.support@se.com and include: * Endpoint URL * Request/Response * Any additional information like Screenshots , Postman collections.

post.description:
### Description 

Identifies the energy model (a.k.a. "thermal signature") of a building, i.e. the relation between its daily or monthly energy consumption and contextual information (weather + other drivers).

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: Specify if the format of the input to the web service should be swagger or not

parameters.name: detailed
parameters.description: The format of the input to the web service

post.description:
### Description 

Uses an existing model to predict the energy that a building would have consumed under given context/usage conditions represented by the provided dataset (containing weather and possibly other drivers). If the actual energy consumption is also provided in the dataset, savings can also be computed, as well as faults.

parameters.name: format
parameters.description: Specify if the format of the input to the web service should be swagger or not

parameters.name: detailed
parameters.description: The format of the input to the web service

post.description:
### Description 

You may wish to use a model created with this component to measure future energy savings, for example after some retrofit operation. But you do not need the same level of quality from your model to measure 2% savings or 30% savings: a much more precise prediction is needed to measure small savings of 2% and be sure that this is not 'just noise'. Also, the shorter the assessment period will be, and the more precise you model needs to be. This service helps you to determine if your model is good enough to measure a given target of energy savings with a given confidence level, based on predictions made during a given number of days (assessment period).

parameters.description: Specify if the format of the input to the web service should be swagger or not

dayGroup.description: Day group to which refer this sub-model.

buildingSignature.description: Building thermal signature of the model.

changePoint1.title: Changepoint1
changePoint1.description:
First change point of the day group model.

* If zero change point : ``None``.
* If at least 1 change point : only ``change_point_1`` has value whatever the model.

changePoint2.title: Changepoint2
changePoint2.description:
Second change point of the day group model.

* If zero change point : ``None``.
* If only one change point : ``None`` 
* If two change points : ``change_point_2`` is NOT ``None``.

targetCol.title: Targetcol
targetCol.description: Name of the column containing the target to predict.

featureCols.title: Featurecols
featureCols.description: Labels of the features used to build the model. Since some features are computed during the model creation, some of these labels may be not present in the input data.

degreeDaysMethod.description: Method used to compute the degree days.

nbObservations.title: Nbobservations
nbObservations.description: Number of observation used to create the model.

nbOutliers.title: Nboutliers
nbOutliers.description: Number of observations detected as outlier when the model were built. These points weren't use to build it.

degreeOfFreedom.title: Degreeoffreedom
degreeOfFreedom.description: Degree of freedom of the model.

regressionCoefficients.title: Regressioncoefficients
regressionCoefficients.description: Coefficients of the different slope of the api_models. The nb of coefficients is equal to the length of ``feature_cols`` field

regressionIntercept.title: Regressionintercept
regressionIntercept.description: Estimated stand by consumption of the building for this day group.

outlierIndexes.title: Outlierindexes
outlierIndexes.description: Row numbers of the observations detected as outlier.

acceptableForSavings.title: Acceptableforsavings
acceptableForSavings.description: Value determining if the model is acceptable to measure savings based on the input requirements. I.e. is the model is sufficient to be sure that data with the input savings are different from data without savings.

maxAcceptableCvrmse.title: Maxacceptablecvrmse
maxAcceptableCvrmse.description: Value representing the maximum coefficient of variation of the root mean squared error(CV(RMSE)).

trueModelUncertainty.title: Truemodeluncertainty
trueModelUncertainty.description: Value representing the true uncertainty of the model.

target.title: Target
target.description: Column containing the target to predict.

minTemperature.title: Mintemperature
minTemperature.description: Column containing the minimal temperature of the day. Unused if `max_temperature` is ``None``

maxTemperature.title: Maxtemperature
maxTemperature.description: Column containing the maximal temperature of the day. Unused if `min_temperature` is ``None``

meanTemperature.title: Meantemperature
meanTemperature.description: Column containing the average temperature of the day.

otherFeatures.title: Otherfeatures
otherFeatures.description: Column list containing other features used to fit the model.

positiveFeatures.title: Positivefeatures
positiveFeatures.description: Column list containing features presenting a positive constraint. The regression coefficient of these features will be forced to be positive if necessary. This list has to be a sub-list of `other_features`.

autoApply.title: Autoapply
autoApply.description:
Define if the model is applied at the end of creation.


There are some differences between a ``create`` with ``auto apply`` and a ``create`` + ``apply``:
1. ``discarded_for_model_creation`` column is added to the prediction.
It shows points in training set not used to fit the final model (regression algorithm automatic selection).
2. `fault_detection` column is computed with a fixed threshold of +/- 2 standard deviation error.
It shows most probable outlier points in training set.
3. `cumulative_prediction_residual` column is computed.
It shows, depending on values patterns, if unknown features might still be influencing selected Target.

degreeDaysMode.description:
Define which degree days formula are going to be computed and tested to create the best model.

+ basic : Compute only basic degree days method.
+ advanced : Compute all computable degree days methods among:
	* `basic`
	* `uk_meteo_office`
	* `fr_energy_professional`

robustRegression.title: Robustregression
robustRegression.description:
Define if the created model is robust to the presence of outliers or not.


Default value = automatic = ``True`` if temporal_resolution is daily resolution, else ``False``.


+ ``True``: An outlier robust linear regression is used to fit the model.
+ ``False``: A standard linear regression is used to fit the model.


.. warning::


If ``temporal_resolution == monthly``, `improve_calendar` cannot be ``True``.

Column containing the day group information


+ If `temporal_resolution == 'monthly'`: Unused.
+ If `day_group_col` is ``None`` and `improve_calendar` is `False`: all observations are analysed together.
+ If `day_group_col` is not `None` and `improve_calendar` is `True`: provided day groups are combined together. The combination leading to the best model is kept.
+ If `day_group_col` is ``None`` and `improve_calendar` is ``True``: a new column containing week days is created. The week day combination leading to the best `BEMModel` is kept.

indexType.description: An optional primitive JSON type name that the index entries should be coerced to, typically 'int' if the index is the row number.

indexName.title: Indexname
indexName.description: An optional index name. If provided, this name must not be present in `columns`.

columns.title: Columns
columns.description: A mandatory set of columns. Each column is identified by its name and should contain one property for each row in the table where this column is non-null. The set of unique property names used in all columns constitute the index column, that therefore does not allow for duplicates.

rows.title: Rows

resolution.title: Temporal resolution
resolution.description:
Temporal resolution of the provided target.


+ daily : All variables are provided daily, i.e. one row represent a day, each value represent the day observation.
+ monthly : All variables except those contained in `target` are provided daily.`target` is provided monthly, i.e. the first day of the month contains the mean energy consumption of the month.


If ``temporal_resolution == monthly``, `improve_calendar` cannot be ``True``.

message.title: Message
message.description: Human readable short explanation of the error
message.default: Found configuration incompatibility with Temporal_resolution and other parametersWhen temporal resolution is monthly, improve_calendar and robust_regression cannot be true, and degree_days_mode cannot be in advanced mode

modelID.description: The model ID of the model to use, as returned by the `createModel` service.

modelIDItem_BEM_assessModelQualityForSav.description: The model ID of the model to use, as returned by the `createModel` service.

day_groups.description: The day group where each day belongs, as used in the final model (one submodel is created for each day group). If `dayGroupsName` was non none and `improveCalendar` was false, this is a copy of the original `dayGroupsName` column. Otherwise you should check the `calendar` and `submodels` outputs for details.

estimated_actual_cdd_contribution.description: An estimation of the actual cooling consumption. This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

cdd.description: The cooling degree days computed with the found optimal degree day method and cooling changepoint, if any.

predicted_oue_contribution.description: The contribution of OUE (Other Usage of Energy, a.k.a. 'daily base load') to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted OUE consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

<targetName>.description: The original target column for reference.

<maxTempName>.description: The original maximum temperature column for reference.

predicted_<driverName>_contribution.description: The contribution of `driver` to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted consumption for usage `driver`. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

NTS_hdd_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_hdd_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for heating when degree days are non-basic.

NTS_<driverName>_predicted_energy.description: This column (line) and `NTS_[driverName]_actual_energy` (dots) should be used as y axis vs. `driverName` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for `driver`.

consumption_anomaly.description: A boolean flag indicating if a sample is a consumption anomaly ('True') or not ('False')

date_time.description: The date without time in ISO8601 format, e.g. '2011-01-30'.

prediction_residual.description: The prediction residual (prediction - actual) for each day. It is positive when the true value is below the prediction, indicating energy consumption savings.

NTS_reftemp_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_reftemp_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for temperature (both heating, cooling and mid season) when degree days are basic.

Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

<minTempName>.description: The original minimum temperature column for reference.

predicted_hdd_contribution.description: The contribution of HDD to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted heating consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

predicted_cdd_contribution.description: The contribution of CDD to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted cooling consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

estimated_actual_<driverName>_contributi.description: An estimation of the actual consumption for usage `driver`. This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

cumulative_savings_<dayGroup>.description: The cumulative sum of prediction residuals for each day group (one column per day group). This contains 'nan' in rows that do not belong to the corresponding day group. The sum of the last non-nan value in all such columns is equal to the last non-nan value in the 'cumulative_savings' column.

<averageTempName>.description: The original average temperature column for reference.

cumulative_savings.description: The cumulative sum of prediction residuals. It increases when the true value is below the prediction, indicating energy consumption savings.

predictionItem_BEM_applyModel.description: A table of predictions, allowing to display the model predictions vs. actual both on timeseries plot and normalized thermal signature plot. Columns are also provided to decompose the prediction and actual consumption by usage (OUE, Cooling, Heating, `driver`). Samples flagged as faults are indicated with the `consumption_anomaly` boolean column, and day groups actually used (indicating which submodel is used to perform the prediction at each row) are provided in the `day_groups` column.

ExecutionRequest_BEM_applyModel.title: Execution request
ExecutionRequest_BEM_applyModel.description: An applyModel request is composed of a dataset provided as a table in the Inputs, a modelID also provided as a 1x1 table in the Inputs, and of a set of parameters in GlobalParameters.

modelID.description: The model ID of the model to use, as returned by the `createModel` service.

modelIDItem_BEM_applyModel.description: The model ID of the model to use, as returned by the `createModel` service.

modelID.description: The model ID of the model to query information about, as returned by the `createModel` service.

modelIDItem_BEM_getModelInformation.description: The model ID of the model to query information about, as returned by the `createModel` service.

confidenceLevel.description: An optional statistical confidence level for statistical tests. This is an advanced parameter.

assessmentPeriod.description: The integer number of days during which the assessment for savings will be made. The larger this number is, the easier it will be to be certain that the savings have been achieved or not. So the larger this number is, the less precise the model used has to be. Conversely, being certain that 5% of savings have been achieved by just looking at a few days (for example one week assessmentPeriod=7) is extremely difficult, and the model will have to be extremely precise to reach the desired level of certainty based on such a poor evidence.

targetSavingsRatio.description: The float ratio between 0 and 1 representing the target level of savings. 1 means 100%, so 20% is 0.2. The smaller this number is, the harder it will be for a model to be good enough to measure the savings: indeed the model prediction error should be a few orders of magnitudes lower than the savings we wish to measure.

uncertaintyRatio.description: The accepted uncertainty about the target savings to be assessed. For example we might wish to measure 20% savings +/- 5%. This uncertainty is a float ratio between 0 and 1.

root_mean_squared_error.description: The root mean squared error (RMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is more sensitive to outliers than the adjMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

median_absolute_error.description: The median absolute error (MedAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

cv_root_mean_squared_error.description: The coefficient of variation of the root mean squared error (CVRMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) relative prediction error', as a percentage of the target (in %). It is more sensitive to outliers than the CVMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

r2_score.description: The RÂ² score represents how better a model is with respect to a dummy model always predicting the average value. 1 means that the model is infinitely better ; 0.75 means that the model is twice better ; 0 means that is it as good ; and negative means that it is worse. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

mean_absolute_error.description: The mean absolute error (MAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

adj_mean_absolute_error.description: The adjusted mean absolute error (MAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

adj_root_mean_squared_error.description: The adjusted root mean squared error (RMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is more sensitive to outliers than the adjMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

auto_correlation.description: The auto correlation of the target value in the provided training dataset.

modelPerformanceItem_BEM_getModelInforma.description: A set of model performance metrics that may be used to check if the created model is of good quality.

data_col.description: name of the column associated to the value

data_row.description: index of the row associated to the value

applyDatasetItem_BEM_applyModel.description: Despite the erroneous name here, this is the table containing new data, for which the model should compute predictions, savings and faults. This table is provided in 'pivoted' format. The unpivoted original table should contain one row per day (daily sampling), and should contain all columns declared in the `datetimeName`, `averageTempName`, `minTemName`, `maxTempName`, `dayGroupsName`, and `driverNames` parameters as used in the `createModel` service that was called to create the model. If column with name corresponding to parameter `targetName` is also provided, savings and fault columns will be added to the predictions table.

<originalDayGroup>.description: The day group used in place of `originalDayGroup` for submodelling / time binning.

calendarItem_BEM_createModel.description: This modeling service is capable of time binning, meaning that the final model is constituted of one or several submodels, one per day group. This table's goal is to explain how the day group is computed when predictions are performed. When parameter `improveCalendar=false`, this table does not bring much information, as it is a self-to-self mapping for each day group. When parameter `improveCalendar=true` however, the day groups originally provided in column `dayGroupName` (or if `dayGroupName='None'`, the days of the week) are merged so as to try to reduce the number of groups (the maximum number of resulting groups is controlled with `maxNbMergedDayGroup`). The resulting mapping is provided in this table: each column name represents the original day group, and each value represents the new day group replacing it.

ExecutionRequest_BEM_createModel.title: Execution request
ExecutionRequest_BEM_createModel.description: A createModel request is composed of a training set provided as a table in the Inputs, and of a set of parameters in GlobalParameters.

positiveDriverNames.description: List of drivers within `driverNames`, that are known to have a positive influence on energy consumption. This list is provided as a string containing coma-separated names.

minTempName.description: Optional name of the column containing the minimum temperature. If provided, sampling inside this column should be daily, and a non-none `maxTempName` should also be provided.

datetimeName.description: Name of the column containing the datetime (sampling should be daily). This column should either contain ISO8601 dates without time (e.g. '2020-01-05') - in which case the `localTimeZone` parameter should not be provided - or ISO8601 dates with the time part (e.g. '2020-01-05T01:00:00+0100') - in which case a non-None `localTimeZone` parameter MUST be provided.

driverNames.description: Optional list of column names, containing drivers that may influence the building's energy consumption, typically process-related information. This list is provided as a string containing coma-separated names. Sampling inside these columns should be daily.

improveCalendar.description: If 'false' (default), the component will create one submodel per day group provided in the `dayGroupsName` column, if any, or create a single model with all samples if no day group is provided. If 'true', the component will try to merge day groups found to have similar behaviour, in the same submodel. This search for calendar improvements takes time.

signatureType.description: Optional parameter to restrict the available model types to a subset. This is a coma-separated list of strings among 'twoParameters', 'threeParametersHeating', 'threeParametersCooling', 'fourParameters', and 'fiveParameters'. Default value 'None' means 'all types without restriction' and is equivalent to 'twoParameters,threeParametersHeating,threeParametersCooling,fourParameters,fiveParameters'.

maxTempName.description: Optional name of the column containing the maximum temperature. If provided, sampling inside this column should be daily, and a non-none `minTempName` should also be provided.

maxNbMergedDayGroups.description: Maximum number of merged day groups that can be created by the component when it tries to improve the calendar (when `improveCalendar=True`).

degreeDaysMethod.description: The subset of degree days methods that should be tried in the model. 'basic' includes 'basic_mean', available if 'averageTempName' is provided, and 'basic_mid', available if 'minTempName' and 'maxTempName' are provided. 'advanced' includes all the basic methods, and in addition contains 'uk_met_office_mean', 'uk_met_office_mid', 'fr_energy_professional_mean', and 'fr_energy_professional_mid'.

dayGroupsName.description: Optional name of the column containing day groups, for example 'Open', 'Closed', etc. If `improveCalendar='False'` one submodel per day group will be created. Otherwise the solver will try to merge day groups together to create more relevant submodels. In that case a maximum number of `maxNbMergedDayGroups` will remain, with a submodel created for each.

targetName.description: Name of the column containing the building energy consumption, in any unit (e.g. kWh, kBTU...). Sampling inside this column should either be daily or monthly, see `temporalResolution` parameter.

temporalResolution.description: If 'daily' (default), a daily model will be created. When 'monthly' is used, the target column should contain a single value at the beginning of each calendar month, or no value at all in a month to indicate that no value is available for this month. This value should correspond to a total energy consumption for the month. This value will then be automatically divided by the number of days in the month before modeling happens. When 'monthly' is used, degreeDaysMethod='advanced' and robustnessMode='robust' are not supported and raise an error.

robustnessMode.description: Robust regression is able to discard outliers to create better models, but takes more time. By default this parameter is 'default', which means 'robust' in daily sampling mode, and 'non_robust' in monhtly sampling.

localTimeZone.description: Optional name of the local timezone in the standard IANA/Olson format e.g. 'Europe/Paris'. If you provide dates without the time e.g. '2010-01-01' then an error will be raised if you provide a non-None `localTimeZone`. Conversely if you provide dates with the time part e.g. 2010-01-01T03:00:00+04:00 then you MUST provide a timezone, e.g. Europe/Paris in this last example would set the provided datetime back to midnight on 2010-01-01.

averageTempName.description: Optional name of the column containing the average temperature. If provided, sampling inside this column should be daily)

faultDetection.description: If set to 'true', the output will include an additional `consumption_anomaly` column flagging the observations considered as abnormal. You can decide to only flag over- or under-consumption faults instead of 'both' (equivalent of 'true').

ExecutionOutputs_BEM_applyModel.title: Execution outputs definition
ExecutionOutputs_BEM_applyModel.description: Results contain a single output named 'prediction'.

predictionItem_BEM_getModelInformation.description: A table of predictions similar to the output of `applyModel`, allowing to display the model predictions vs. actual both on timeseries plot and normalized thermal signature plot. Columns are also provided to decompose the prediction and actual consumption by usage (OUE, Cooling, Heating, `driver`). Samples discarded for model creation are indicated with the `discarded_for_model_creation` boolean column, and day groups actually used (indicating which submodel is used to perform the prediction at each row) are provided in the `day_groups` column.

<originalDayGroup>.description: The day group used in place of `originalDayGroup` for submodelling / time binning.

calendarItem_BEM_getModelInformation.description: This modeling service is capable of time binning, meaning that the final model is constituted of one or several submodels, one per day group. This table's goal is to explain how the day group is computed when predictions are performed. When parameter `improveCalendar=false`, this table does not bring much information, as it is a self-to-self mapping for each day group. When parameter `improveCalendar=true` however, the day groups originally provided in column `dayGroupName` (or if `dayGroupName='None'`, the days of the week) are merged so as to try to reduce the number of groups (the maximum number of resulting groups is controlled with `maxNbMergedDayGroup`). The resulting mapping is provided in this table: each column name represents the original day group, and each value represents the new day group replacing it.

ExecutionRequest_BEM_getModelInformation.title: Execution request
ExecutionRequest_BEM_getModelInformation.description: A getModelInformation request is composed of a modelID provided as a 1x1 table in the Inputs.

nb_training_samples.description: The number of training samples used to fit this model. The sum of `nb_training_samples` across all submodels is equal to the global `modelInfo.nb_training_samples`. For each submodel, the sum of `nb_training_samples` and `nb_outliers` is equal to the number of samples provided in the `trainDataset` table that correspond to this `dayGroup`.

change_points.description: A string representing the list of changepoints in this model, with format '[`val`,...]'. The number of elements in this list may be zero, one or two depending if the model is a 'twoParameters', 'three/fourParameters' or 'fiveParameters'.

drivers.description: A string representing the list of drivers used by this model, with format '[`val`,...]'. This list is used as a reference to know to which driver each coefficient corresponds (in `coefficients`).

r2_score.description: The RÂ² score represents how better a model is with respect to a dummy model always predicting the average value. 1 means that the model is infinitely better ; 0.75 means that the model is twice better ; 0 means that is it as good ; and negative means that it is worse. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

mean_absolute_error.description: The mean absolute error (MAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

adj_root_mean_squared_error.description: The adjusted root mean squared error (RMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is more sensitive to outliers than the adjMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

nb_model_parameters.description: The total number of parameters in this submodel, that is, the number of coefficiens plus the number of changepoints. The sum of `nb_model_parameters` for all submodels is equal to the global `modelInfo.nb_model_parameters`.

day_group.description: The day group this submodel is associated with. This is one of the day groups in the `calendar` output mapping.

auto_correlation.description: The auto correlation of the target value in the provided training dataset.

intercept.description: The intercept in this model's equation.

root_mean_squared_error.description: The root mean squared error (RMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is more sensitive to outliers than the adjMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

absolute_error_std.description: The standard deviation of the error (so, the RMSE), for each part of the model, for example: {'cdd': None, 'hdd': 880.28, 'middle_temp': 361.21}

coefficients.description: A string representing the list of coefficients (slopes) in this model's equation, for each driver in the same order as in `drivers`. The intercept is provided separately in `intercept`.

median_absolute_error.description: The median absolute error (MedAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

cv_root_mean_squared_error.description: The coefficient of variation of the root mean squared error (CVRMSE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) relative prediction error', as a percentage of the target (in %). It is more sensitive to outliers than the CVMAE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

degree_days_method.description: The degree days method used to compute degree days for this submodel. One of 'basic_mean', 'basic_mid', 'uk_met_office_mean', 'uk_met_office_mid', 'fr_energy_professional_mean', and 'fr_energy_professional_mid'.

adj_mean_absolute_error.description: The adjusted mean absolute error (MAE) can be seen as an 'average (absolute) prediction error', in the unit of the target (e.g. kWh). It is less sensitive to outliers than the adjRMSE. It takes into account all predictions on the training set including those made on discarded points not used for fitting.

nb_outliers.description: Number of training samples in this day group discarded from model fitting, because they contained a missing driver or target or were considered outliers by the robust regression solver. For each submodel, the sum of `nb_training_samples` and `nb_outliers` is equal to the number of samples provided in the `trainDataset` table that correspond to this `dayGroup`.

signature_type.description: The thermal signature type of this submodel. One of 'twoParameters', 'threeParametersHeating', 'threeParametersCooling', 'fourParameters', 'fiveParameters'.

submodelsItem_BEM_createModel.description: This modeling service is capable of time binning, meaning that the final model is constituted of one or several submodels, one per day group. The `calendar` output contains the mapping explaining how day groups are computed. This `submodels` table provides information about the associated submodel for each day group: coefficients, number of samples, and also performance metrics.

ExecutionOutputs_BEM_assessModelQualityF.title: Execution outputs definition
ExecutionOutputs_BEM_assessModelQualityF.description: Results contain a single output named 'modelQual'.

ExecutionResults_BEM_assessModelQualityF.title: Execution Results
ExecutionResults_BEM_assessModelQualityF.description: Results contain a single output named 'modelQual'.

max_acceptable_cvrmse.description: A number indicating the maximum CVRMSE allowed for a model to be acceptable.

true_model_uncertainty.description: A number indicating the CVRMSE of the selected model.

acceptable_for_savings.description: A boolean indicating if this model has acceptable precision to compute the savings under the conditions and expectations described in the parameters.

creation_date.description: Date of model creation in ISO8601 format.

nb_outliers.description: Number of training samples discarded from model fitting, because they contained a missing driver or target or were considered outliers by the robust regression solver. The sum of `nb_training_samples` and `nb_outliers` is equal to the number of samples provided in the `trainDataset` table.

nb_training_samples.description: Number of training samples actually used to fit the model. The sum of `nb_training_samples` and `nb_outliers` is equal to the number of samples provided in the `trainDataset` table.

modelID.description: Represents the identification of the created model, which is securely stored on the Schneider Electric platform. This ID can be used to refer to a model in the `applyModel`, `getModelInformation`, `assessModelQualityForSavings` and `deleteModel` services.

nb_model_parameters.description: The total number of parameters in the model. It is the sum of the number of regression coefficients and changepoints in all submodels.

modelInfoItem_BEM_createModel.description: Basic essential information about the created model, including its creation date and model ID.

day_groups.description: The day group where each day belongs, as used in the final model (one submodel is created for each day group). If `dayGroupsName` was non none and `improveCalendar` was false, this is a copy of the original `dayGroupsName` column. Otherwise you should check the `calendar` and `submodels` outputs for details.

estimated_actual_cdd_contribution.description: An estimation of the actual cooling consumption. This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

cdd.description: The cooling degree days computed with the found optimal degree day method and cooling changepoint, if any.

predicted_oue_contribution.description: The contribution of OUE (Other Usage of Energy, a.k.a. 'daily base load') to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted OUE consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

<targetName>.description: The original target column for reference.

<maxTempName>.description: The original maximum temperature column for reference.

predicted_<driverName>_contribution.description: The contribution of `driver` to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted consumption for usage `driver`. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

discarded_for_model_creation.description: A boolean flag indicating if a sample was discarded before fitting the model ('True') or not ('False')

NTS_hdd_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_hdd_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for heating when degree days are non-basic.

NTS_<driverName>_predicted_energy.description: This column (line) and `NTS_[driverName]_actual_energy` (dots) should be used as y axis vs. `driverName` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for `driver`.

date_time.description: The date without time in ISO8601 format, e.g. '2011-01-30'.

prediction_residual.description: The prediction residual (prediction - actual) for each day. It is positive when the true value is below the prediction, indicating energy consumption savings.

NTS_reftemp_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_reftemp_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for temperature (both heating, cooling and mid season) when degree days are basic.

estimated_actual_hdd_contribution.description: An estimation of the actual heating consumption. This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

NTS_hdd_predicted_energy.description: This column (line) and `NTS_hdd_actual_energy` (dots) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for heating when degree days are non-basic.

NTS_<driverName>_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_[driverName]_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `driverName` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for `driver`.

<minTempName>.description: The original minimum temperature column for reference.

predicted_hdd_contribution.description: The contribution of HDD to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted heating consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

middleTemp.description: The middle temperature computed when `minTempName` and `maxTempName` are provided, as `(minTemp+maxTemp) / 2`.

estimated_actual_oue_contribution.description: An estimation of the actual OUE consumption (Other Usage of Energy, a.k.a. 'daily base load'). This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

reference_temperature.description: The reference temperature column used by the model. This column is a copy of either the `middleTemp` or the `averageTempName` column.

fault_detection_lower_limit.description: The upper limit for fault detection, for information. Note that in this service no fault detection is performed, so this is just an indicator of how the model would behave for detecting faults.

NTS_reftemp_predicted_energy.description: This column (line) and `NTS_reftemp_actual_energy` (dots) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for temperature (both heating, cooling and mid season) when degree days are basic.

fault_detection_upper_limit.description: The upper limit for fault detection, for information. Note that in this service no fault detection is performed, so this is just an indicator of how the model would behave for detecting faults.

hdd.description: The heating degree days computed with the found optimal degree day method and heating changepoint, if any.

predicted_cdd_contribution.description: The contribution of CDD to the 'prediction' column: this is the predicted cooling consumption. At each row, the sum of all 'predicted_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the 'prediction' column.

estimated_actual_<driverName>_contributi.description: An estimation of the actual consumption for usage `driver`. This estimation is made by applying to the `target` the same usage prorata as in the `prediction`. Therefore at each row, the sum of all 'estimated_actual_[name]_contribution' columns is equal to the `targetName` column.

cumulative_savings_<dayGroup>.description: The cumulative sum of prediction residuals for each day group (one column per day group). This contains 'nan' in rows that do not belong to the corresponding day group. The sum of the last non-nan value in all such columns is equal to the last non-nan value in the 'cumulative_savings' column.

NTS_cdd_actual_energy.description: This column (dots) and `NTS_cdd_predicted_energy` (line) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for cooling when degree days are non-basic.

<averageTempName>.description: The original average temperature column for reference.

NTS_cdd_predicted_energy.description: This column (line) and `NTS_cdd_actual_energy` (dots) should be used as y axis vs. `reference_temperature` (x axis) to plot the normalized thermal signature for cooling when degree days are non-basic.

cumulative_savings.description: The cumulative sum of prediction residuals. It increases when the true value is below the prediction, indicating energy consumption savings.

predictionItem_BEM_createModel.description: A table of predictions similar to the output of `applyModel`, allowing to display the model predictions vs. actual both on timeseries plot and normalized thermal signature plot. Columns are also provided to decompose the prediction and actual consumption by usage (OUE, Cooling, Heating, `driver`). Samples discarded for model creation are indicated with the `discarded_for_model_creation` boolean column, and day groups actually used (indicating which submodel is used to perform the prediction at each row) are provided in the `day_groups` column.

modelPerformanceItem_BEM_createModel.description: A set of model performance metrics that may be used to check if the created model is of good quality.

creation_date.description: Date of model creation in ISO8601 format.

Error401.title: Authorization Error
Error401.description: Error occurred while authorizing the request (based on rfc7807)

type.description: A URI reference [RFC3986] that identifies the problem type.

title.description: A short, human-readable summary of the problem type.

status.description: The HTTP status code ([RFC7231], Section 6) generated by the origin server for this occurrence of the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.
